alert.note: Alert for Yavapai (Arizona) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued March 21 at 1:07PM MST until March 23 at 5:34AM MST by NWS Flagstaff
info.description: ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM MST WEDNESDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by rain and snowmelt continues. * WHERE...Portions of north central Arizona including southern Coconino County and eastern Yavapai County. The greatest threat of flooding will be for Dry Beaver Creek, Wet Beaver Creek, and West Clear Creek. * WHEN...Until 700 PM MST Wednesday. * IMPACTS...Flooding of creeks and normally dry washes is occurring. Yavapai County Emergency Management reported flooding on Beaver Vista Road and Rimrock Drive in Rimrock. Wet Beaver Creek near Rimrock is expected to crest at 11.5 feet at 9 AM MST Wednesday, reaching Moderate Flood Stage in the early morning Wednesday and remain above Minor Flood Stage through 600 PM MST Wednesday evening. West Clear Creek will crest at 8.8 feet at 9 AM MST Wednesday. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1257 PM MST, rain and snowmelt is occurring and will cause flooding. Between 0.50 and 1.00 inches of rain have fallen. - This includes the following creeks, washes and rivers...Dry Beaver Creek, Wet Beaver Creek, and West Clear Creek along with Long Canyon, Jacks Canyon, Rarick Canyon, Walker Creek, and Rattlesnake Canyon. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.5 to 1.25 inches are possible in the warned area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Rimrock, Montezuma Well, Lake Montezuma, Mcguireville, Montezuma Castle National Monument, V Bar V Visitors Center, Wet Beaver Creek Campground and Clear Creek Campgrounds. - This includes the following swimming holes... Wet Beaver Creek Day Use Area, Bell Crossing "The Crack", Bull Pen Day Use Area, West Clear Creek near the campground and Indian Maiden Falls. This includes the following highways... State Route 260 between mile markers 223 and 227...and near mile marker 229. Interstate 17 between mile markers 291 and 306. State Route 179 between mile markers 299 and 307. - Visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for more information on flood safety.
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. In hilly or mountainous terrain, there are many low water crossings which will become dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route. Remain alert for flooding even in locations not receiving rain. Normally dry washes, slot canyons and creeks can become raging killer currents in a matter of minutes, even from distant rainfall.
